Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Committee of Safety joined forces, with U.S. diplomat John L. Stevens and a show of force by the U.S. marines aboard the U.S.S. Boston, to overthrow the Queen because she
Options: A. Wanted to sign a new constitution, B. Refused to sign another treaty with the U.S., C. Visited Great Britain, D. Wanted more ships to dock in Honolulu Harbor
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: On what date was Queen Lili'uokalani arrested? Options: A. January 16th, 1893, B. January 16th, 1895, C. January 17th, 1893, D. January 17th, 1895 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who declared Hawaii a US territory on July 7th, 1898? Options: A. President William McKinley, B. Queen Lili'uokalani, C. The Committee of Safety, D. The Provisional Government Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the primary effect of the Bayonet Constitution on the monarchy's power? Options: A. It strengthened the monarchy's power and control over the government., B. It had no significant impact on the monarchy's power., C. It diminished the monarchy's power and ceded control to white businessmen., D. It led to the immediate overthrow of the monarchy. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why did the Committee of Safety stage a coup on January 17th, 1893? Options: A. To address legitimate concerns about the safety of American citizens and property., B. To protect American property and lives from perceived danger and to further their own interests., C. To overthrow the monarchy and establish a new government based on democratic principles., D. To support Queen Lili'uokalani's proposed constitution. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What lesson can be learned from the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy? Options: A. The importance of imperialism in expanding a nation's influence and modernizing colonized territories., B. The dangers of imperialism and the importance of preserving indigenous cultures and respecting sovereignty., C. The need for a strong military presence to maintain control and order in colonized territories., D. The benefits of colonialism in bringing modernization and progress to colonized peoples. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can the story of Queen Lili'uokalani be applied to modern-day struggles? Options: A. As a cautionary tale about the dangers of democracy and self-determination for indigenous peoples., B. As a symbol of resistance against colonialism and a testament to the enduring power of indigenous cultures and identities., C. As a justification for the annexation of territories and the suppression of native populations in the name of progress., D. As a historical footnote with no relevance to modern-day issues of colonialism, imperialism, and indigenous rights. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the primary factor that contributed to the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy? Options: A. The arrival of American missionaries and their influence on the government and Native Hawaiian society., B. The economic interests of the sugar trade and its impact on the Native Hawaiian people and their land., C. The military might of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government in imposing their will on the monarchy., D. The combination of economic interests, cultural differences, and the influence of American missionaries. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the significance of the contrast between the Bayonet Constitution and Queen Lili'uokalani's proposed constitution? Options: A. It highlighted the similarities between the two documents and the shared interests of the white businessmen and the Native Hawaiian people., B. It demonstrated the irrelevance of constitutional documents in shaping the course of Hawaiian history., C. It highlighted the conflicting interests of the white businessmen and the Native Hawaiian people, particularly regarding land ownership and voting rights., D. It showed the willingness of Queen Lili'uokalani to compromise and negotiate with her opponents. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the turning point in Hawaiian history that marked the beginning of the end of the monarchy and the eventual annexation by the US? Options: A. The arrival of American missionaries in Hawaii and their influence on the government., B. The signing of the Bayonet Constitution and its impact on the monarchy's power., C. The combination of the Bayonet Constitution and the Committee of Safety's coup, which effectively ended the monarchy's control., D. The establishment of the Provisional Government and its declaration of Hawaii as a republic. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the driving force behind the overthrow of the monarchy? Options: A. The intersection of economic interests (sugar trade) and cultural differences (American missionaries vs. Native Hawaiians)., B. The military might of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government in imposing their will on the monarchy., C. The weakness of Queen Lili'uokalani's leadership and her inability to adapt to changing circumstances., D. The arrival of American missionaries and their influence on the government. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the actions of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government be judged? Options: A. As morally justifiable, given the circumstances and the need for change in Hawaii., B. As morally reprehensible, given their role in the overthrow of the monarchy, the disenfranchisement of Native Hawaiians, and the annexation of Hawaii., C. As historically insignificant, with no lasting impact on Hawaiian history or the lives of Native Hawaiians., D. As a necessary evil, required to bring modernization and progress to Hawaii. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the significance of Queen Lili'uokalani's determination to restore power to her people? Options: A. It was a futile effort that ultimately led to her downfall and the annexation of Hawaii., B. It was a heroic act of defiance against colonialism, and her legacy can be evaluated as a powerful symbol of resistance and resilience for Native Hawaiians., C. It was a pragmatic decision, driven by a desire to maintain her own power and influence in the face of changing circumstances., D. It was an irrelevant gesture, with no lasting impact on Hawaiian history or the lives of Native Hawaiians. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 4. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions focus on the reasons behind the Committee of Safety's actions, specifically their staging of a coup against Queen Lili'uokalani. The correct options in both questions (B in Question 4 and A in the ground truth MCQ) convey the idea that the Committee of Safety's actions were motivated by a desire to protect American interests and further their own goals, rather than a legitimate concern for the safety of American citizens or property.

While the wording of the questions and options differs slightly, the overall intent and content of Question 4 aligns most closely with the ground truth MCQ. 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long was Queen Liliʻuokalani imprisoned in ʻIolani Palace?
Options: A. 2 years, B. 4 months, C. 8 months , D. 10 months
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

Question: When Queen Liliʻuokalani was jailed, she passed her time by
Options: A. Making a patchwork quilt, B. Writing songs, C. Reading newspapers, brought to her wrapped around flowers from her garden, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

It was an irrelevant gesture, with no lasting impact on Hawaiian history or the lives of Native Hawaiians. Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It was January 16th, 1895. Two men arrived at Lili’uokalani’s door,
arrested her, and led her to the room
where she would be imprisoned. A group had recently seized power
and now confiscated her diaries, ransacked her house, 
claimed her lands, and hid her away. Lili’uokalani was Hawaii’s queen. And she ruled through one of the most
turbulent periods of its history. 75 years earlier, American missionaries
first arrived in Hawaii. They quickly amassed power,
building businesses and claiming arable land 
that they transformed into plantations. They worked closely with the ali’i, or sacred Hawaiian nobility 
closely linked to the Gods. The ali’i appointed missionaries 
to government roles where they helped establish Hawaii 
as a sovereign kingdom with a constitutional monarchy. But once certain business 
opportunities emerged— namely, the prospect of exporting sugar
to the US tariff-free— some of their descendants
shifted positions. They formed a political group 
known as “the Missionary Party” and began plotting to annex Hawaii,
bringing it under US control. Lili’uokalani and her siblings were born
into an ali’i family. In 1874, her brother, Kalākaua, 
ascended the throne, but thirteen years into his reign,
the emerging threat crystallized. The Missionary Party called a meeting
where an all-white militia surrounded and forced the king 
to sign new legislation. Later called the Bayonet Constitution, it stripped Native Hawaiians 
of their rights, diminished the monarchy’s power, and ceded control to this group
of white businessmen. Four years later, King Kalākaua died, heartbroken, Lili’uokalani said, “by the base ingratitude of the very 
persons whose fortunes he had made.” Prepared to fight, she assumed the throne. Despite death threats 
and rumors of insurgency, Queen Lili’uokalani was determined
to restore power to her people— an estimated two thirds of whom 
had lost their voting rights. Flooded with requests for change, 
she authored a new constitution. But before she introduced it, 
the so-called “Committee of Safety,” a new organization that consisted 
of many Missionary Party members, hatched another plot. Under the false pretense 
that this new constitution endangered American property and lives, they staged a coup on January 17th, 1893. More than 160 US Marines
marched to the palace, where the “Committee of Safety” 
removed Queen Lili’uokalani from office. Thousands of Hawaiian people protested, some wearing hat bands reading, 
“Aloha ’Āina,” or “love of the nation.” The alleged “Provisional Government”
declared Hawaii a Republic the following year. They proclaimed 
that Hawaiians couldn’t vote or be government employees without signing
a new “oath of allegiance.” Many refused. The following year, 
some of Lili’uokalani’s supporters attempted a counterrevolution. The Republic responded brutally, jailing hundreds
and sentencing six people to death. In exchange for their release, the Republic made Lili’uokalani 
sign a document that claimed to relinquish her throne,
and they imprisoned her in the palace. Under constant guard, she composed songs 
expressing her love for her people and began making a patchwork quilt
that told the story of her life. While she was only allowed news
that had been reviewed by her jailers, her supporters often brought her bouquets
from the garden she’d dedicated to them, wrapped in newspaper. After 8 months, Lili’uokalani was placed 
under house arrest. As soon as it was lifted, she traveled
to Washington, D.C. with Hawaiian nationalists
and over 20,000 signatures. There they successfully convinced Congress
to halt the Republic’s annexation treaty. But the following year, 
the Spanish-American War began. Seeing Hawaii 
as a strategic military base, President William McKinley declared 
it a US territory on July 7th, 1898— breaking international law and devastating
Queen Lili’uokalani and her people. She spent the rest of her life petitioning
for the restoration of her lands, Native Hawaiian rights, 
and national liberation. When she died in 1917, 
these dreams were unrealized. A member of the group that forced 
Queen Lili’uokalani out of office once declared, “If we are ever to have 
peace and annexation the first thing to do 
is obliterate the past.” They failed at this goal. Queen Lili’uokalani left
a resilient legacy: Her commitment to her land and people
never wavered and many Hawaiians continue to fight
in her memory. Speaking of Hawaii’s children,
Queen Lili’uokalani said, “It is for them that I would give
the last drop of my blood.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Aloha ʻĀina patriots protested
Options: A. World War I, B. Civil War, C. Spanish-American War, D. None of the Above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: On what date was Queen Lili'uokalani arrested? Options: A. January 16th, 1893, B. January 16th, 1895, C. January 17th, 1893, D. January 17th, 1895 Correct Option: B
Question 2: Who declared Hawaii a US territory on July 7th, 1898? Options: A. President William McKinley, B. Queen Lili'uokalani, C. The Committee of Safety, D. The Provisional Government Correct Option: A
Question 3: What was the primary effect of the Bayonet Constitution on the monarchy's power? Options: A. It strengthened the monarchy's power and control over the government., B. It had no significant impact on the monarchy's power., C. It diminished the monarchy's power and ceded control to white businessmen., D. It led to the immediate overthrow of the monarchy. Correct Option: C
Question 4: Why did the Committee of Safety stage a coup on January 17th, 1893? Options: A. To address legitimate concerns about the safety of American citizens and property., B. To protect American property and lives from perceived danger and to further their own interests., C. To overthrow the monarchy and establish a new government based on democratic principles., D. To support Queen Lili'uokalani's proposed constitution. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What lesson can be learned from the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy? Options: A. The importance of imperialism in expanding a nation's influence and modernizing colonized territories., B. The dangers of imperialism and the importance of preserving indigenous cultures and respecting sovereignty., C. The need for a strong military presence to maintain control and order in colonized territories., D. The benefits of colonialism in bringing modernization and progress to colonized peoples. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can the story of Queen Lili'uokalani be applied to modern-day struggles? Options: A. As a cautionary tale about the dangers of democracy and self-determination for indigenous peoples., B. As a symbol of resistance against colonialism and a testament to the enduring power of indigenous cultures and identities., C. As a justification for the annexation of territories and the suppression of native populations in the name of progress., D. As a historical footnote with no relevance to modern-day issues of colonialism, imperialism, and indigenous rights. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the primary factor that contributed to the overthrow of the Hawaiian monarchy? Options: A. The arrival of American missionaries and their influence on the government and Native Hawaiian society., B. The economic interests of the sugar trade and its impact on the Native Hawaiian people and their land., C. The military might of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government in imposing their will on the monarchy., D. The combination of economic interests, cultural differences, and the influence of American missionaries. Correct Option: D
Question 8: What was the significance of the contrast between the Bayonet Constitution and Queen Lili'uokalani's proposed constitution? Options: A. It highlighted the similarities between the two documents and the shared interests of the white businessmen and the Native Hawaiian people., B. It demonstrated the irrelevance of constitutional documents in shaping the course of Hawaiian history., C. It highlighted the conflicting interests of the white businessmen and the Native Hawaiian people, particularly regarding land ownership and voting rights., D. It showed the willingness of Queen Lili'uokalani to compromise and negotiate with her opponents. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What was the turning point in Hawaiian history that marked the beginning of the end of the monarchy and the eventual annexation by the US? Options: A. The arrival of American missionaries in Hawaii and their influence on the government., B. The signing of the Bayonet Constitution and its impact on the monarchy's power., C. The combination of the Bayonet Constitution and the Committee of Safety's coup, which effectively ended the monarchy's control., D. The establishment of the Provisional Government and its declaration of Hawaii as a republic. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What was the driving force behind the overthrow of the monarchy? Options: A. The intersection of economic interests (sugar trade) and cultural differences (American missionaries vs. Native Hawaiians)., B. The military might of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government in imposing their will on the monarchy., C. The weakness of Queen Lili'uokalani's leadership and her inability to adapt to changing circumstances., D. The arrival of American missionaries and their influence on the government. Correct Option: A
Question 11: How can the actions of the Committee of Safety and the Provisional Government be judged? Options: A. As morally justifiable, given the circumstances and the need for change in Hawaii., B. As morally reprehensible, given their role in the overthrow of the monarchy, the disenfranchisement of Native Hawaiians, and the annexation of Hawaii., C. As historically insignificant, with no lasting impact on Hawaiian history or the lives of Native Hawaiians., D. As a necessary evil, required to bring modernization and progress to Hawaii. Correct Option: B
Question 12: What was the significance of Queen Lili'uokalani's determination to restore power to her people? Options: A. It was a futile effort that ultimately led to her downfall and the annexation of Hawaii., B. It was a heroic act of defiance against colonialism, and her legacy can be evaluated as a powerful symbol of resistance and resilience for Native Hawaiians., C. It was a pragmatic decision, driven by a desire to maintain her own power and influence in the face of changing circumstances., D. It was an irrelevant gesture, with no lasting impact on Hawaiian history or the lives of Native Hawaiians. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that shares a similar theme and intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the event that Aloha ʻĀina patriots protested. While none of the generated MCQs directly ask about this event, Question 4 discusses the coup staged by the Committee of Safety, which is related to the protests.

However, a more relevant question is Question 9, which asks about the turning point in Hawaiian history that marked the beginning of the end of the monarchy and the eventual annexation by the US. One of the options (C) mentions the combination of the Bayonet Constitution and the Committee of Safety's coup, which is related to the protests.

But the most relevant question is Question 10, which asks about the driving force behind the overthrow of the monarchy. One of the options (A) mentions the intersection of economic interests (sugar trade) and cultural differences (American missionaries vs. Native Hawaiians), which is related to the protests.

Considering these questions, I would say that Question 10 is the most similar generated MCQ, as it discusses the underlying factors that led to the protests and the overthrow of the monarchy.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 10

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What, you want my milkshake? Here. “It’s 1819. As the United States Congress prepares 
to make Missouri the 24th state in the Union, Representative James Tallmage Jr. 
delivers a speech. He says slavery is morally wrong, calling it an ‘abomination’
and a ‘monstrous scourge.’ He insists that ‘the extension 
of the evil must now be prevented,’ and that slavery shouldn’t be allowed 
in Missouri, or any new state.” Obviously. “Representative Tyler disagrees. He believes it is a state’s right 
to choose whether or not to allow slavery. He doesn’t think the federal government
can prohibit slavery in any newly added states.” Whaaaaat? “Senator Thomas proposes
what he sees as a compromise: Missouri will join the union along
with another state, Maine. Slavery will be allowed in Missouri
and prohibited in Maine. He also suggests drawing a line 
through territories yet to become states: slavery will be prohibited north 
of the line, and allowed south of it.” And this is where I have
to draw the line. That’s better. Now, senators, congressmen, this Missouri compromise you are proposing
is fundamentally flawed— flawed is putting it mildly. The compromise is based 
on the middle ground fallacy. By saying that half of the new territories
should allow slavery while half prohibit it, you position the two viewpoints,
pro-slavery and anti-slavery, as equally valid. But if one view is wrong,
while the other is right, a compromise between them is still wrong. And one side is definitely wrong here:
the pro-slavery side. The whole reason this government exists, the whole reason states exist at all, 
is to serve the people. That should include all people. Now, I know there are those 
among you who would argue otherwise, even among those in favor
of ending slavery. In response to your many contorted
arguments, all of them wrong, I offer this reminder: the idea that slavery 
is morally indefensible is not new to you. The founders of your country knew it
and many even acknowledged it publicly, even those of them who enslaved
other people themselves. It’s clear that the errors and delusions
on this subject go far beyond the middle ground fallacy, but I call your attention 
to this particular fallacy because it can have dire consequences
in many situations. Failure to recognize the fact 
that a compromise between two positions, one of which is morally indefensible,
is also morally indefensible, has helped to perpetuate countless
injustices large and small. Even well-intentioned people—
which rest assured, I don’t mistake you for—
fall prey to this fallacy, because you humans tend to view compromise
as a virtue unto itself. “It’s March 1861. Seven states have seceded from the Union since Abraham Lincoln 
was elected president. As Lincoln takes office with four more
states threatening to leave, he promises not to interfere with slavery
in states where it exists, but to prohibit its expansion 
into new territories and states.” “It’s April 1861, and a Civil War
has broken out over slavery.” Some things can't be resolved
with a compromise.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The addition of a slave state with a free state in the mid-1800s is an example of what kind of logical fallacy?
Options: A. Appeal to Popular Opinion, B. Correlation Implies Causation, C. Middle Ground, D. Slippery Slope
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In 1819, who delivered a speech to the United States Congress, calling slavery an "abomination" and a "monstrous scourge"? Options: A. Representative Tyler, B. Senator Thomas, C. Representative James Tallmage Jr., D. Abraham Lincoln Correct Option: C
Question 2: What was the outcome of the Missouri Compromise regarding slavery in new territories? Options: A. Slavery was prohibited in all new territories., B. Slavery was allowed in all new territories., C. A line was drawn through new territories, prohibiting slavery north of the line and allowing it south of it., D. Slavery was only allowed in Missouri. Correct Option: C
Question 3: What was the primary reason for the debate over slavery in the United States, as evident in the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. Economic disagreements between states., B. Disagreements over state rights versus federal power., C. Moral disagreements over the institution of slavery., D. Foreign policy disagreements. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the primary goal of the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. To abolish slavery in all states., B. To balance the power between pro-slavery and anti-slavery states., C. To establish a new federal law., D. To create a new state. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the speaker's main critique of the concept of compromise, as seen in the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. That it is always the best solution., B. That it is a necessary evil., C. That it can be morally indefensible when one side is wrong., D. That it is never possible. Correct Option: C
Question 6: How can the debate over slavery be applied to modern-day discussions about human rights and equality? Options: A. By recognizing that some human rights are more important than others., B. By acknowledging that human rights and equality are still contentious issues., C. By ignoring the historical context of the debate over slavery., D. By assuming that human rights and equality are no longer relevant issues. Correct Option: B
Question 7: According to the speaker, what was a consequence of the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. It led to the immediate abolition of slavery., B. It perpetuated the idea that slavery was morally justifiable., C. It had no significant impact on the debate over slavery., D. It led to the secession of only one state. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What contrast does the speaker highlight between the pro-slavery and anti-slavery views? Options: A. That both views are morally equivalent., B. That one view is morally wrong, while the other is morally right., C. That both views are economically viable., D. That both views are politically expedient. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How can the speaker's argument about the middle ground fallacy be applied to the concept of human rights? Options: A. By recognizing that human rights are always subject to compromise., B. By acknowledging that some human rights are more important than others., C. By understanding that moral absolutism is necessary in certain situations to protect human rights., D. By assuming that human rights are never absolute. Correct Option: C
Question 10: What new understanding can be formed by synthesizing the debate over slavery with modern-day discussions about systemic racism and inequality? Options: A. That slavery has no ongoing impact on American society., B. That systemic racism and inequality are separate issues from slavery., C. That the legacy of slavery continues to affect American society today., D. That slavery was only a minor issue in American history. Correct Option: C
Question 11: What is the speaker's main critique of the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. That it was a necessary evil., B. That it was a morally justifiable compromise., C. That it was fundamentally flawed and morally indefensible., D. That it had no significant impact on the debate over slavery. Correct Option: C
Question 12: How does the speaker justify their position on the Missouri Compromise? Options: A. By citing the founders' support for slavery., B. By ignoring the historical context of the compromise., C. By citing the founders' acknowledgment of slavery's moral indefensibility and the dire consequences of perpetuating the middle ground fallacy., D. By assuming that the compromise was necessary for the unity of the country. Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: 

"What is the speaker's main critique of the concept of compromise, as seen in the Missouri Compromise? 
Options: A. That it is always the best solution., B. That it is a necessary evil., C. That it can be morally indefensible when one side is wrong., D. That it is never possible."

However, an even more similar question is Question 9: 

"How can the speaker's argument about the middle ground fallacy be applied to the concept of human rights? 
Options: A. By recognizing that human rights are always subject to compromise., B. By acknowledging that some human rights are more important than others., C. By understanding that moral absolutism is necessary in certain situations to protect human rights., D. By assuming that human rights are never absolute."

But the most similar question is actually Question 11's justification in Question 12 and then more specifically Question 5's idea of moral indefensibility being expanded upon in Question 9, however the actual most similar question is Question 9.

However the question that is most similar in content is actually Question 5.

What, you want my milkshake? Here. “It’s 1819. As the United States Congress prepares 
to make Missouri the 24th state in the Union, Representative James Tallmage Jr. 
delivers a speech. He says slavery is morally wrong, calling it an ‘abomination’
and a ‘monstrous scourge.’ He insists that ‘the extension 
of the evil must now be prevented,’ and that slavery shouldn’t be allowed 
in Missouri, or any new state.” Obviously. “Representative Tyler disagrees. He believes it is a state’s right 
to choose whether or not to allow slavery. He doesn’t think the federal government
can prohibit slavery in any newly added states.” Whaaaaat? “Senator Thomas proposes

and prohibited in Maine. He also suggests drawing a line 
through territories yet to become states: slavery will be prohibited north 
of the line, and allowed south of it.” And this is where I have
to draw the line. That’s better. Now, senators, congressmen, this Missouri compromise you are proposing
is fundamentally flawed— flawed is putting it mildly. The compromise is based

Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
What, you want my milkshake? Here. “It’s 1819. As the United States Congress prepares 
to make Missouri the 24th state in the Union, Representative James Tallmage Jr. 
delivers a speech. He says slavery is morally wrong, calling it an ‘abomination’
and a ‘monstrous scourge.’ He insists that ‘the extension 
of the evil must now be prevented,’ and that slavery shouldn’t be allowed 
in Missouri, or any new state.” Obviously. “Representative Tyler disagrees. He believes it is a state’s right 
to choose whether or not to allow slavery. He doesn’t think the federal government
can prohibit slavery in any newly added states.” Whaaaaat? “Senator Thomas proposes
what he sees as a compromise: Missouri will join the union along
with another state, Maine. Slavery will be allowed in Missouri
and prohibited in Maine. He also suggests drawing a line 
through territories yet to become states: slavery will be prohibited north 
of the line, and allowed south of it.” And this is where I have
to draw the line. That’s better. Now, senators, congressmen, this Missouri compromise you are proposing
is fundamentally flawed— flawed is putting it mildly. The compromise is based 
on the middle ground fallacy. By saying that half of the new territories
should allow slavery while half prohibit it, you position the two viewpoints,
pro-slavery and anti-slavery, as equally valid. But if one view is wrong,
while the other is right, a compromise between them is still wrong. And one side is definitely wrong here:
the pro-slavery side. The whole reason this government exists, the whole reason states exist at all, 
is to serve the people. That should include all people. Now, I know there are those 
among you who would argue otherwise, even among those in favor
of ending slavery. In response to your many contorted
arguments, all of them wrong, I offer this reminder: the idea that slavery 
is morally indefensible is not new to you. The founders of your country knew it
and many even acknowledged it publicly, even those of them who enslaved
other people themselves. It’s clear that the errors and delusions
on this subject go far beyond the middle ground fallacy, but I call your attention 
to this particular fallacy because it can have dire consequences
in many situations. Failure to recognize the fact 
that a compromise between two positions, one of which is morally indefensible,
is also morally indefensible, has helped to perpetuate countless
injustices large and small. Even well-intentioned people—
which rest assured, I don’t mistake you for—
fall prey to this fallacy, because you humans tend to view compromise
as a virtue unto itself. “It’s March 1861. Seven states have seceded from the Union since Abraham Lincoln 
was elected president. As Lincoln takes office with four more
states threatening to leave, he promises not to interfere with slavery
in states where it exists, but to prohibit its expansion 
into new territories and states.” “It’s April 1861, and a Civil War
has broken out over slavery.” Some things can't be resolved
with a compromise.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why was the Missouri Compromise fundamentally flawed?
Options: A. The compromise was based on the middle ground fallacy., B. The legislators assumed that the two viewpoints, pro-slavery and anti-slavery, were equally valid., C. The United States was founded on self-evident truths that all men are created equal with the same unalienable rights to life liberty and the pursuit of happiness., D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

Slavery was allowed in all new territories., C. A line was drawn through new territories, prohibiting slavery north of the line and allowing it south of it., D. Slavery was only allowed in Missouri. That the legacy of slavery continues to affect American society today., D. That slavery was only a minor issue in American history. Correct Option: C

That it was fundamentally flawed and morally indefensible., D. That it had no significant impact on the debate over slavery. Correct Option: C

By ignoring the historical context of the compromise., C. By citing the founders' acknowledgment of slavery's moral indefensibility and the dire consequences of perpetuating the middle ground fallacy., D. By assuming that the compromise was necessary for the unity of the country. Correct Option: C

Question 11: What is the speaker's main critique of the Missouri Compromise? 
Options: A. That it was a necessary evil., B. That it was a morally justifiable compromise., C. That it was fundamentally flawed and morally indefensible., D. That it had no significant impact on the debate over slavery. 
Correct Option: C

This question aligns with the ground truth MCQ, which asks why the Missouri Compromise was fundamentally flawed. The correct option in the generated MCQ (C) matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D), which states that the compromise was fundamentally flawed because it was based on the middle ground fallacy and assumed that the two viewpoints (pro-slavery and anti-slavery) were equally valid.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
What, you want my milkshake? Here. “It’s 1819. As the United States Congress prepares 
to make Missouri the 24th state in the Union, Representative James Tallmage Jr. 
delivers a speech. He says slavery is morally wrong, calling it an ‘abomination’
and a ‘monstrous scourge.’ He insists that ‘the extension 
of the evil must now be prevented,’ and that slavery shouldn’t be allowed 
in Missouri, or any new state.” Obviously. “Representative Tyler disagrees. He believes it is a state’s right 
to choose whether or not to allow slavery. He doesn’t think the federal government
can prohibit slavery in any newly added states.” Whaaaaat? “Senator Thomas proposes
what he sees as a compromise: Missouri will join the union along
with another state, Maine. Slavery will be allowed in Missouri
and prohibited in Maine. He also suggests drawing a line 
through territories yet to become states: slavery will be prohibited north 
of the line, and allowed south of it.” And this is where I have
to draw the line. That’s better. Now, senators, congressmen, this Missouri compromise you are proposing
is fundamentally flawed— flawed is putting it mildly. The compromise is based 
on the middle ground fallacy. By saying that half of the new territories
should allow slavery while half prohibit it, you position the two viewpoints,
pro-slavery and anti-slavery, as equally valid. But if one view is wrong,
while the other is right, a compromise between them is still wrong. And one side is definitely wrong here:
the pro-slavery side. The whole reason this government exists, the whole reason states exist at all, 
is to serve the people. That should include all people. Now, I know there are those 
among you who would argue otherwise, even among those in favor
of ending slavery. In response to your many contorted
arguments, all of them wrong, I offer this reminder: the idea that slavery 
is morally indefensible is not new to you. The founders of your country knew it
and many even acknowledged it publicly, even those of them who enslaved
other people themselves. It’s clear that the errors and delusions
on this subject go far beyond the middle ground fallacy, but I call your attention 
to this particular fallacy because it can have dire consequences
in many situations. Failure to recognize the fact 
that a compromise between two positions, one of which is morally indefensible,
is also morally indefensible, has helped to perpetuate countless
injustices large and small. Even well-intentioned people—
which rest assured, I don’t mistake you for—
fall prey to this fallacy, because you humans tend to view compromise
as a virtue unto itself. “It’s March 1861. Seven states have seceded from the Union since Abraham Lincoln 
was elected president. As Lincoln takes office with four more
states threatening to leave, he promises not to interfere with slavery
in states where it exists, but to prohibit its expansion 
into new territories and states.” “It’s April 1861, and a Civil War
has broken out over slavery.” Some things can't be resolved
with a compromise.

Correct Option: B

to make Missouri the 24th state in the Union, Representative James Tallmage Jr. 
delivers a speech. He says slavery is morally wrong, calling it an ‘abomination’
and a ‘monstrous scourge.’ He insists that ‘the extension 
of the evil must now be prevented,’ and that slavery shouldn’t be allowed 
in Missouri, or any new state.” Obviously. “Representative Tyler disagrees. He believes it is a state’s right 
to choose whether or not to allow slavery. He doesn’t think the federal government
can prohibit slavery in any newly added states.” Whaaaaat? “Senator Thomas proposes
what he sees as a compromise: Missouri will join the union along
with another state, Maine. Slavery will be allowed in Missouri
and prohibited in Maine. He also suggests drawing a line 
through territories yet to become states: slavery will be prohibited north 
of the line, and allowed south of it.” And this is where I have
to draw the line. That’s better. Now, senators, congressmen, this Missouri compromise you are proposing
is fundamentally flawed— flawed is putting it mildly. The compromise is based 
on the middle ground fallacy. By saying that half of the new territories
should allow slavery while half prohibit it, you position the two viewpoints,
pro-slavery and anti-slavery, as equally valid. But if one view is wrong,
while the other is right, a compromise between them is still wrong. And one side is definitely wrong here:
the pro-slavery side. The whole reason this government exists, the whole reason states exist at all, 
is to serve the people. That should include all people. Now, I know there are those 
among you who would argue otherwise, even among those in favor
of ending slavery. In response to your many contorted
arguments, all of them wrong, I offer this reminder: the idea that slavery 
is morally indefensible is not new to you. The founders of your country knew it
and many even acknowledged it publicly, even those of them who enslaved
other people themselves. It’s clear that the errors and delusions
on this subject go far beyond the middle ground fallacy, but I call your attention 
to this particular fallacy because it can have dire consequences
in many situations. Failure to recognize the fact 
that a compromise between two positions, one of which is morally indefensible,
is also morally indefensible, has helped to perpetuate countless
injustices large and small. Even well-intentioned people—
which rest assured, I don’t mistake you for—
fall prey to this fallacy, because you humans tend to view compromise
as a virtue unto itself. “It’s March 1861. Seven states have seceded from the Union since Abraham Lincoln 
was elected president. As Lincoln takes office with four more
states threatening to leave, he promises not to interfere with slavery
in states where it exists, but to prohibit its expansion 
into new territories and states.” “It’s April 1861, and a Civil War
has broken out over slavery.” Some things can't be resolved
with a compromise.
